00064 namespace phys
00065 {
00066     class ActorContainerBase;
00067     class World;
00068     namespace internal
00069     {
00070         class PhysMotionState;

00073     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00074     /// @class ActorBase
00075     /// @headerfile actorbase.h
00076     /// @brief This is the base class from which all the actors inherit.
00077     /// @details The actor classes store and manage all the relevant data regarding
00078     /// objects inside the World.  They serve as a binder between the physics and
00079     /// graphics for objects and have functions that allow the manipulation of objects
00080     /// loaded into the World.  Currently there are 5 actor classes: ActorBase,
00081     /// ActorRigid, ActorSoft, ActorTerrain, ActorRagDoll. @n
00082     /// ActorBase is a base class that serves as a template for the other four actor classes. @n
00083     /// ActorBase should never be created, as it lacks the functionality needed for most objects.
00084     ///////////////////////////////////////
00085     class PHYS_LIB ActorBase {
00086         private:
00087             friend class Node;
00088             friend class ActorContainerBase;
00089             friend class PhysicsManager;
00090             friend class ResourceManager;
00091 
00092         public:
00093             /// @enum ActorTypeName
00094             /// @brief A listing of Actor TypeNames
00095             /// @details These will be returned by ActorBase::GetType(), and will allow
00096             /// code using this to determine what type of Actor class they are working with
00097             /// and use this information to more safely cast to the correct Actor if needed.
00098             enum ActorTypeName
00099             {
00100                 Actorbase,
00101                 Actorragdoll,
00102                 Actorrigid,
00103                 Actorsoft,
00104                 Actorterrain
00105             };
00106 
00107         protected:
00108             /// @brief A pointer to the World the actor will reside.
00109             World* GameWorld;
00110 
00111             //abstraction for other libraries
00112             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the Ogre::Entity using this
00113             Ogre::Entity* entity;
00114 
00115             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the Ogre::SceneNode using this
00116             Ogre::SceneNode* node;
00117 
00118             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the Ogre::AnimationState using this
00119             Ogre::AnimationState* Animation;
00120 
00121             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the btCollisionShape using this
00122             btCollisionShape* Shape;
00123 
00124             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the btCollisionObject using this
00125             btCollisionObject* CollisionObject;
00126 
00127             ///@brief This class encapsulates the functionality of the PhysMotionState using this
00128             internal::PhysMotionState* MotionState;
00129 
00130             /// @brief This variable stores the type of actor that this class is.
00131             ActorTypeName ActorType;
00132 
00133             /// @brief Stores whether or not the current physics shape has been saved in the manager.
00134             bool ShapeIsSaved;
00135 
00136             /// @brief Creates a trimesh shape from the mesh file.
00137             /// @details Makes a trimesh to be used as a collision shape in the physics world from a mesh file. @n
00138             /// This is automaticly called by the CreateShapeFromMesh function in child classes and shouldn't be called manually.
00139             btTriangleMesh* CreateTrimesh() const;
00140 
00141 //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00142 // Ogre Management Functions
00143 ///////////////////////////////////////
00144             /// @brief Gets the ogre resource manager pointer.
00145             /// @details This function is needed for the ActorSoft implementation.
00146             /// @return Returns a pointer to the ogre resource group manager.
00147             Ogre::ResourceGroupManager* GetOgreResourceManager();
00148 
00149             /// @brief Gets the verticy information of the mesh this soft body is based on.
00150             /// @details This function will read the mesh provided and gather the verticies inside it for re-use.
00151             /// @param TheMesh The struct to populate with the information gathered.
00152             void GetMeshVerticies (internal::MeshInfo &TheMesh);
00153 
00154             /// @brief Gets the indicy information of the mesh this soft body is based on.
00155             /// @details This function will read the mesh provided and gather the indicies inside it for re-use.
00156             /// @param TheMesh The struct to populate with the information gathered.
00157             void GetMeshIndicies (internal::MeshInfo &TheMesh);
00158 
00159             /// @brief Gets the normals information of the mesh this soft body is based on.
00160             /// @details This function will read the mesh provided and gather the normals of each verticy inside it for re-use.
00161             /// @param TheMesh The struct to populate with the information gathered.
00162             void GetMeshNormals (internal::MeshInfo &TheMesh);
00163 
00164             /// @brief Gets the texture coordinates information of the mesh this soft body is based on.
00165             /// @details This function will read the mesh provided and gather the texture coordinates inside it for re-use.
00166             /// @param TheMesh The struct to populate with the information gathered.
00167             void GetMeshTextures (internal::MeshInfo &TheMesh);
00168 
00169             /// @brief Gets other information not related to the verticies from the mesh.
00170             /// @details This function will get the Render Operation, Material Name, and Entity Name from the entity for re-use.
00171             /// @param TheMesh The struct to populate with the information gathered.
00172             void GetOtherMeshInfo (internal::MeshInfo &TheMesh);
00173 
00174             /// @brief Creates an entity for the mesh file to be placed on a scene node.
00175             /// @details Creates an entity in the scene manager from the mesh file provided to be attached to a node in the graphical world. @n
00176             /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00177             /// @param name Name of the actor.
00178             /// @param file File name of the graphical mesh to be used.
00179             /// @param group Resource group where the graphical mesh can be found.
00180             void CreateEntity(String name, String file, String group);
00181 
00182             /// @brief Creates a node for the entity in the graphical world.
00183             /// @details Creates a node in the scene manager to attach the actor's entity to within the graphical world. @n
00184             /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00185             void CreateSceneNode();
00186 
00187             /// @brief Sets the location of the graphical body.
00188             /// @details This will take a Vector3 and set the location of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00189             /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00190             /// @param Place The Vector3 representing the location.
00191             void SetOgreLocation(Vector3 Place);
00192 
00193             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the graphical body.
00194             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the graphical world. This should always match the physics world.
00195             /// @return This returns a phys::Vector3 with the location of the graphics.
00196             Vector3 GetOgreLocation() const;
00197 
00198             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the graphical body.
00199             /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00200             /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00201             /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00202             void SetOgreOrientation (Quaternion Rotation);
00203 
00204             /// @brief Makes the actor visable.
00205             /// @details Adds the actor to all the nessessary graphics elements to make it visable on screen. @n
00206             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't ever need to be called manually.
00207             virtual void AttachToGraphics();
00208 
00209             /// @brief Makes the actor invisable.
00210             /// @details This is the inverse of the AttachToGraphics function.  This will effectively remove the object from the graphics world and make it no longer visable. @n
00211             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds RemoveActor function and shouldn't ever need to be called manually.
00212             virtual void DetachFromGraphics();
00213 
00214 //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00215 // Bullet Management
00216 ///////////////////////////////////////
00217             /// @brief Creates a motion state for use with syncronizing physics and graphics.
00218             /// @details This is a helper function that will create a motionstate for the class.  This is called on by the constructor.
00219             /// @param Node The node to be syncronized with physics data.
00220             virtual void CreateMotionState(Ogre::SceneNode* Node);
00221 
00222             /// @brief Creates a motion state for use with syncronizing physics and graphics.
00223             /// @details This is a helper function that will create a motionstate for the class.  This is called on by the constructor.
00224             /// @param Node The node to be syncronized with physics data.
00225             /// @param InitPosition The starting location for the object that will be given this motionstate.
00226             virtual void CreateMotionState(Ogre::SceneNode* Node, Vector3 InitPosition);
00227 
00228             /// @brief Creates a motion state for use with syncronizing physics and graphics.
00229             /// @details This is a helper function that will create a motionstate for the class.  This is called on by the constructor.
00230             /// @param Node The node to be syncronized with physics data.
00231             /// @param InitPosition The starting location for the object that will be given this motionstate.
00232             /// @param InitOrientation The starting orientation for the object that will be given this motionstate.
00233             virtual void CreateMotionState(Ogre::SceneNode* Node, Vector3 InitPosition, Quaternion InitOrientation);
00234 
00235             /// @brief Sets the location of the physics body.
00236             /// @details This will take a Vector3 and set the location of the actor within the physics world. @n
00237             /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00238             /// @param Location The Vector3 representing the location.
00239             virtual void SetBulletLocation (Vector3 Location);
00240 
00241             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the physics body.
00242             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the physics world.
00243             virtual Vector3 GetBulletLocation() const;
00244 
00245             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the physics body.
00246             /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the physics world. @n
00247             /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00248             /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00249             virtual void SetBulletOrientation (Quaternion Rotation);
00250 
00251         public:
00252             ///@brief This is a collection of sounds for use with this actor.
00253             SoundSet* ActorSounds;
00254 
00255             /// @brief Gets the type of actor this class is.
00256             /// @details This function will get the type of class that you are working with for checking and casting.
00257             /// @return ActorTypeName The type of actor that this is.
00258             virtual int GetType();
00259 
00260             /// @brief Gets whether this actors current shape has been saved or not.
00261             /// @details This function will tell you if it's current physics shape has been saved for later use or not.
00262             /// @return Returns whether or not the shape of this actor has been saved.
00263             const bool GetShapeIsSaved();
00264 
00265             /// @brief Sets the basic parameters for more realistic collision behavior.
00266             /// @details This function will set the Friction and Resititution of the actor, which will enable it to collide
00267             /// and interact with other actors in a game world more realistically.
00268             /// @param Friction Should be self explanitory, higher values will resist sliding across surfaces.  This number is the
00269             /// coefficient of friction.  Range is from 0.0 to 2.0.  Behavior in this regard is determined by the friction of both
00270             /// colliding bodies.  @n Default: 0.5
00271             /// @param Restitution The coefficient of restitution determines how much energy is left after a collision with an object.
00272             /// Range is from 0.0 to 1.0.  Behavior in this regard is determined by the restitution of both colliding bodies.
00273             /// @n Default: 0.0
00274             void SetBasicCollisionParams(Real Friction, Real Restitution);
00275 
00276             /// @brief Sets the animation for this object.
00277             /// @details This function will get the specified animation for this object stored in the mesh file, and will loop the
00278             /// animation if specified.
00279             /// @param AnimationName Name of the stored animation to be loaded.
00280             /// @param Loop Whether or not you want the animation to loop.  For example, you would want an idle animation to loop,
00281             /// but not a death animation.
00282             void SetAnimation(ConstString &AnimationName, bool Loop);
00283 
00284             /// @brief Enables the animation if one is set.
00285             /// @details This function will enable the animation if passed true, making the object animate.  If passed false will
00286             /// disable the animation.
00287             /// @param Enable True to enable the animation or false to disable the animation.
00288             void EnableAnimation(bool Enable);
00289 
00290             /// @brief Tells whether this actor is animated or not.
00291             /// @details This function will return true if the actor has an animation set and it is enabled.
00292             /// @return Returns true if an animation is set and enabled.
00293             bool IsAnimated();
00294 
00295             /// @brief Advances the animation, making it animate.
00296             /// @details You need to call this every frame while the actor is to be animated, otherwise even with the animation
00297             /// enabled you will see no change in the animation.
00298             void AdvanceAnimation(Real Time);
00299 
00300             /// @brief Unloads a loaded animation.
00301             /// @details This function will remove the existing set animation.
00302             void RemoveSetAnimation();
00303 
00304 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00305 // Creation, Destruction and Initialization
00306 ///////////////////////////////////////
00307 
00308             /// @brief Destructor.
00309             /// @details The class destructor.
00310             virtual ~ActorBase ();
00311 
00312             /// @brief Descriptive constructor.
00313             /// @details This constructor contains the basic information needed to make an actor.
00314             /// @param name The name of the actor.
00315             /// @param file The 3d mesh file that contains the 3d model the actor will use.
00316             /// @param group The resource group where the 3d mesh and other related files can be found.
00317             ActorBase (String name, String file, String group);
00318 
00319             /// @brief Sets the starting location of the actor.
00320             /// @details Calling this function after adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00321             /// This function will set where the actor will be located in the World when it is first placed inside the world.
00322             /// @param Location The Vector3 representing the location.
00323             virtual void SetInitLocation(Vector3 Location);
00324 
00325             /// @brief Sets the starting orientation of the actor.
00326             /// @details Calling this function after adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00327             /// This function will set where the actor is facing in the World when it is first placed inside the world.
00328             /// @param Orientation The PhysQuaternion representing the Orientation.
00329             virtual void SetInitOrientation(Quaternion Orientation);
00330 
00331             /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00332             /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00333             /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00334             /// @param x Location on the X vector.
00335             /// @param y Location on the Y vector.
00336             /// @param z Location on the Z vector.
00337             virtual void SetLocation(Real x, Real y, Real z);
00338 
00339             /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00340             /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00341             /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00342             /// @param Place The Vector3 representing the location.
00343             virtual void SetLocation(Vector3 Place);
00344 
00345             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the object.
00346             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the world.
00347             virtual Vector3 GetLocation() const;
00348 
00349             /// @brief Retrieves the name of the object.
00350             /// @details This function will retrieve the name of the object,
00351             virtual std::string GetName() const = 0;
00352 
00353             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00354             /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via Quaternion parameters.
00355             /// @param x Where the X vector is rotated about.
00356             /// @param y Where the Y vector is rotated about.
00357             /// @param z Where the Z vector is rotated about.
00358             /// @param w How much to about the x, y, z.
00359             virtual void SetOrientation(Real x, Real y, Real z, Real w);
00360 
00361             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00362             /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via a Quaternion.
00363             /// @param Rotation The Quaternion representing the Rotation.
00364             virtual void SetOrientation(Quaternion Rotation);
00365 
00366             /// @brief Sets the scale of the actor.
00367             /// @details This function will alter the scaling/size of the actor with the given vector3.
00368             /// @param scale The vector3 by which to apply the scale.  Will scale each axis' accordingly.
00369             void SetActorScaling(Vector3 scale);
00370 
00371             /// @brief Creates a collision shape from mesh file.
00372             /// @details This function will read the location of every verticy in the mesh file and use that to
00373             /// construct a triangle mesh shape and attach it to this objects collision shape.  This shoiuld
00374             /// be used with only with Dynamic objects.
00375             /// @param accuracy A short unsigned int, the higher the more accurate, but the more resource intensive. This is Actor dependent
00376             virtual void CreateShapeFromMeshDynamic(short unsigned int accuracy ) = 0;
00377 
00378 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00379 // Working with the World
00380 ///////////////////////////////////////
00381             /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00382             /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00383             /// This is automatically called by the phys::Actors::AddActor function and Doesn't neet to be called manually.
00384             /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the World class.
00385             virtual void AddObjectToWorld(World* TargetWorld) = 0;
00386 
00387             /// @brief Removes the actor from the physics world.
00388             /// @details Removes the actor from the physics world. @n
00389             /// This is automatically called by the phys::Actors::AddActor function and Doesn't neet to be called manually.
00390             /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the World class.
00391             virtual void RemoveObjectFromWorld(World* TargetWorld) = 0;
00392 
00393 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00394 // Public Collision flag functions
00395 ///////////////////////////////////////
00396             /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Kinematic.
00397             /// @details This function will set the object to a Kinematic Object. @n
00398             /// Kinematic Objects are like Static Objects but are also able to be moved directly by character controllers.
00399             void SetKinematic();
00400 
00401             /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Static.
00402             /// @details This function will set the object to a Static Object. @n
00403             /// Static Objects don't move or have any force applied to them, but are cabable of exerting force on other objects.
00404             void SetStatic();
00405 
00406             /// @brief Checks of the actor is static or kinematic.
00407             /// @details Checks of the actor is static or kinematic, returns true if it is either.
00408             /// @return Returns true if the actor is static or kinematic.
00409             bool IsStaticOrKinematic();
00410 
00411             /// @brief Sets the actor to be able to collide with other objects in the world.
00412             /// @details By default collision response is enabled.  Only call this function if you have disabled collision response.
00413             void EnableCollisionResponse();
00414 
00415             /// @brief Sets the actor to be unable to collide with other objects in the world.
00416             /// @details By default collision response is enabled.  Be sure to reactivate collision response if you want your objects to collide again.
00417             void DisableCollisionResponse();
00418 
00419             /// @brief Checks if the object is active in the simulation.
00420             /// @return Returns true if the object is active, false if it's deactivated(at rest).
00421             bool CheckActivation();
00422     };
